CONJUGATES: frenzies (n. pl.) | frenzies (v. 3rd sg. pres.) | frenzied (v. past t. & p.p.) | frenzying (v. pres. p.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French frenesie, from Latin phrenesis, from Greek phrenitis 'delirium', from phren 'mind'.

MEANINGS.PATTERN: [sb/sth] in a frenzy | a frenzy of [sth]
MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A state or period of uncontrolled excitement or wild behavior.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一种无法控制的兴奋或狂躁行为的状态或时期。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The crowd worked itself into a frenzy as the band came on stage.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 乐队上台时，人群陷入了狂热状态。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Verb: a word used to describe an action, state, or occurrence, and forming the main part of the predicate of a sentence.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To make someone frantic or greatly excited; to throw into a frenzy.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 使某人狂乱或极度兴奋；使陷入疯狂。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The sudden news frenzied the investors, causing a market panic.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 突如其来的消息使投资者陷入疯狂，导致市场恐慌。

REGISTER: Often used in descriptive or literary contexts, but also common in everyday speech to describe intense excitement.
